Description: Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.

Subject: Math
Description: Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.

Subject: Math
Description: Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length difference in terms of a standard length unit.

Subject: Math
Description: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as drawings of rulers) and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

Subject: Math
Description: Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2, É , and represent whole-number sums and differences within 100 on a number line diagram.

Subject: Math
Description: Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m.

Subject: Math
Description: Solve word problems involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies, using $ (dollars) and ¢ (cents) symbols appropriately. Example: If you have 2 dimes and 3 pennies, how many cents do you have?

Subject: Math
Description: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths of several objects to the nearest whole unit, or by making repeated measurements of the same object. Show the measurements by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in whole-number units.

Subject: Math
Description: Draw a picture graph and a bar graph (with single-unit scale) to represent a data set with up to four categories. Solve simple put-together, take-apart, and compare problems using information presented in a bar graph.

Subject: Math
Description: Recognize and draw shapes having specified attributes, such as a given number of angles or a given number of equal faces. Identify triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and cubes. (Sizes are compared directly or visually, not compared by measuring.)

Subject: Math
Description: Partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size squares and count to find the total number of them.

Subject: Math
Description: Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, thirds, half of, a third of, etc., and describe the whole as two halves, three thirds, four fourths. Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes need not have the same shape.

Subject: Math
Description: Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

Subject: Math
Description: Solve word problems that call for addition of three whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

Subject: Math
Description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract. Examples: If 8 + 3 = 11 is known, then 3 + 8 = 11 is also known. (Commutative property of addition.) To add 2 + 6 + 4, the second two numbers can be added to make a ten, so 2 + 6 + 4 = 2 + 10 = 12. (Associative property of addition.) (Students need not use formal terms for these properties.)

Subject: Math
Description: Understand subtraction as an unknown-addend problem. For example, subtract 10 - 8 by finding the number that makes 10 when added to 8.

Subject: Math
Description: Relate counting to addition and subtraction (e.g., by counting on 2 to add 2).

Subject: Math
Description: Add and subtract within 20, demonstrating fluency for addition and subtraction within 10. Use strategies such as counting on; making ten (e.g., 8 + 6 = 8 + 2 + 4 = 10 + 4 = 14); decomposing a number leading to a ten (e.g., 13 - 4 = 13 - 3 - 1 = 10 - 1 = 9); using the relationship between addition and subtraction (e.g., knowing that 8 + 4 = 12, one knows 12 - 8 = 4); and creating equivalent but easier or known sums (e.g., adding 6 + 7 by creating the known equivalent 6 + 6 + 1 = 12 + 1 = 13).

Subject: Math
Description: Understand the meaning of the equal sign, and determine if equations involving addition and subtraction are true or false. For example, which of the following equations are true and which are false? 6 = 6, 7 = 8 - 1, 5 + 2 = 2 + 5, 4 + 1 = 5 + 2.

Subject: Math
Description: Determine the unknown whole number in an addition or subtraction equation relating three whole numbers. For example, determine the unknown number that makes the equation true in each of the equations 8 + ? = 11, 5 = ? - 3, 6 + 6 = ?.

Subject: Math
Category: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Description: Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120. In this range, read and write numerals and represent a number of objects with a written numeral.

Subject: Math
Category: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Description: Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones. Understand the following as special cases:

Subject: Math
Category: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Description: 10 can be thought of as a bundle of ten ones - called a "ten".

Subject: Math
Category: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Description: The numbers from 11 to 19 are composed of a ten and a one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.

Subject: Math
Category: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Description: The numbers 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.

Subject: Math
Category: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Description: Compare two two-digit numbers based on meanings of the tens and ones digits, recording the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, and <.

Subject: Math
Category: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Description: Add within 100, including adding a two-digit number and a one-digit number, and adding a two-digit number and a multiple of 10, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used. Understand that in adding two-digit numbers, one adds tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose a ten.

Subject: Math
Category: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Description: Given a two-digit number, mentally find 10 more or 10 less than the number, without having to count; explain the reasoning used.

Subject: Math
Category: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Description: Subtract multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 from multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 (positive or zero differences), using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.

Subject: Math
Description: Order three objects by length; compare the lengths of two objects indirectly by using a third object.

Subject: Math
Description: Express the length of an object as a whole number of length units, by laying multiple copies of a shorter object (the length unit) end to end; understand that the length measurement of an object is the number of same-size length units that span it with no gaps or overlaps. Limit to contexts where the object being measured is spanned by a whole number of length units with no gaps or overlaps.

Subject: Math
Description: Tell and write time in hours and half-hours using analog and digital clocks.

Subject: Math
Description: Organize, represent, and interpret data with up to three categories; ask and answer questions about the total number of data points, how many in each category, and how many more or less are in one category than in another.

Subject: Math
Description: Distinguish between defining attributes (e.g., triangles are closed and three-sided) versus non-defining attributes (e.g., color, orientation, overall size); for a wide variety of shapes; build and draw shapes to possess defining attributes.

Subject: Math
Description: Compose two-dimensional shapes (rectangles, squares, trapezoids, triangles, half-circles, and quarter-circles) or three-dimensional shapes (cubes, right rectangular prisms, right circular cones, and right circular cylinders) to create a composite shape, and compose new shapes from the composite shape. (Students do not need to learn formal names such as "right rectangular prism.")

Subject: Math
Description: Partition circles and rectangles into two and four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, fourths, and quarters, and use the phrases half of, fourth of, and quarter of. Describe the whole as two of, or four of the shares. Understand for these examples that decomposing into more equal shares creates smaller shares.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Print many upper- and lowercase letters.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Form regular plural nouns orally by adding /s/ or /es/ (e.g., dog, dogs; wish, wishes).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Understand and use question words (interrogatives) (e.g., who, what, where, when, why, how).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use the most frequently occurring prepositions (e.g., to, from, in, out, on, off, for, of, by, with).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Produce and expand complete sentences in shared language activities.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Capitalize the first word in a sentence and the pronoun I.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Recognize and name end punctuation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write a letter or letters for most consonant and short-vowel sounds (phonemes).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Spell simple words phonetically, drawing on knowledge of sound-letter relationships.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on kindergarten reading and content.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Identify new meanings for familiar words and apply them accurately (e.g., knowing duck is a bird and learning the verb to duck).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use the most frequently occurring inflections and affixes (e.g., -ed, -s, re-, un-, pre-, -ful, -less) as a clue to the meaning of an unknown word.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With guidance and support from adults, explore word relationships and nuances in word meanings.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Sort common objects into categories (e.g., shapes, foods) to gain a sense of the concepts the categories represent.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate understanding of frequently occurring verbs and adjectives by relating them to their opposites (antonyms).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Identify real-life connections between words and their use (e.g., note places at school that are colorful).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Distinguish shades of meaning among verbs describing the same general action (e.g., walk, march, strut, prance) by acting out the meanings.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use words and phrases acquired through conversations, reading and being read to, and responding to texts.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate understanding of the organization and basic features of print.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Follow words from left to right, top to bottom, and page by page.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Recognize that spoken words are represented in written language by specific sequences of letters.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Understand that words are separated by spaces in print.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Recognize and name all upper- and lowercase letters of the alphabet.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate understanding of spoken words, syllables, and sounds (phonemes).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Recognize and produce rhyming words.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Count, pronounce, blend, and segment syllables in spoken words.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Blend and segment onsets and rimes of single-syllable spoken words.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: d. Isolate and pronounce the initial, medial vowel, and final sounds (phonemes) in three-phoneme (consonant-vowel-consonant, or CVC) words.*(This does not include CVCs ending with /l/, /r/,or /x/.)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Add or substitute individual sounds (phonemes) in simple, one-syllable words to make new words.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Know and apply grade-level phonics and word analysis skills in decoding words.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate basic knowledge of letter-sound correspondences by producing the primary or most frequent sound for each consonant.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Associate the long and short sounds with the common spellings (graphemes) for the five major vowels.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Read common high-frequency words by sight. (e.g., the, of, to, you, she, my, is, are, do, does).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Distinguish between similarly spelled words by identifying the sounds of the letters that differ.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Read emergent-reader texts with purpose and understanding.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, ask and answer questions about key details in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, identify the main topic and retell key details of a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, describe the connection between two individuals, events, ideas, or pieces of information in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, ask and answer questions about unknown words in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Identify the front cover, back cover, and title page of a book.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Name the author and illustrator of a text and define the role of each in presenting the ideas or information in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, describe the relationship between illustrations and the text in which they appear (e.g., what person, place, thing, or idea in the text an illustration depicts).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, identify the reasons an author gives to support points in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, identify basic similarities in and differences between two texts on the same topic (e.g., in illustrations, descriptions, or procedures).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity
Description: Actively engage in group reading activities with purpose and understanding.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, ask and answer questions about key details in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, retell familiar stories, including key details.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, identify characters, settings, and major events in a story.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Ask and answer questions about unknown words in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Recognize common types of texts (e.g., storybooks, poems).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, name the author and illustrator of a story and define the role of each in telling the story.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, describe the relationship between illustrations and the story in which they appear (e.g., what moment in a story an illustration depicts).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With prompting and support, compare and contrast the adventures and experiences of characters in familiar stories.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity
Description: Actively engage in group reading activities with purpose and understanding.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Participate in collaborative conversations with diverse partners about kindergarten topics and texts with peers and adults in small and larger groups.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Follow agreed-upon rules for discussions (e.g., listening to others and taking turns speaking about the topics and texts under discussion).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Continue a conversation through multiple exchanges.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Confirm understanding of a text read aloud or information presented orally or through other media by asking and answering questions about key details and requesting clarification if something is not understood.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Ask and answer questions in order to seek help, get information, or clarify something that is not understood.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Describe familiar people, places, things, and events and, with prompting and support, provide additional detail.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Add drawings or other visual displays to descriptions as desired to provide additional detail.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Speak audibly and express thoughts, feelings, and ideas clearly.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use a combination of drawing, dictating, and writing to compose opinion pieces in which they tell a reader the topic or the name of the book they are writing about and state an opinion or preference about the topic or book (e.g., My favorite book is . . .)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use a combination of drawing, dictating, and writing to compose informative/explanatory texts in which they name what they are writing about and supply some information about the topic.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use a combination of drawing, dictating, and writing to narrate a single event or several loosely linked events, tell about the events in the order in which they occurred, and provide a reaction to what happened.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With guidance and support from adults, respond to questions and suggestions from peers and add details to strengthen writing as needed.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With guidance and support from adults, explore a variety of digital tools to produce and publish writing, including in collaboration with peers.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Participate in shared research and writing projects (e.g., explore a number of books by a favorite author and express opinions about them).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: With guidance and support from adults, recall information from experiences or gather information from provided sources to answer a question.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Explain the function of verbals (gerunds, participles, infinitives) in general and their function in particular sentences.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Form and use verbs in the active and passive voice.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Form and use verbs in the indicative, imperative, interrogative, conditional, and subjunctive mood.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb voice and mood.*

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use punctuation (comma, ellipsis, dash) to indicate a pause or break.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use an ellipsis to indicate an omission.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Spell correctly.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use verbs in the active and passive voice and in the conditional and subjunctive mood to achieve particular effects (e.g., emphasizing the actor or the action; expressing uncertainty or describing a state contrary to fact).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a word’s position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., precede, recede, secede).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning or its part of speech.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Interpret figures of speech (e.g. verbal irony, puns) in context.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use the relationship between particular words to better understand each of the words.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Distinguish among the connotations (associations) of words with similar denotations (definitions) (e.g., bullheaded, willful, firm, persistent, resolute).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using different mediums (e.g., print or digital text, video, multimedia) to present a particular topic or idea.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze a case in which two or more texts provide conflicting information on the same topic and identify where the texts disagree on matters of fact or interpretation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity
Description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literary nonfiction at the high end of the grades 6–8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Compare and contrast the structure of two or more texts and analyze how the differing structure of each text contributes to its meaning and style.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze the extent to which a filmed or live production of a story or drama stays faithful to or departs from the text or script, evaluating the choices made by the director or actors.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how a modern work of fiction draws on themes, patterns of events, or character types from myths, traditional stories, or religious works such as the Bible, including describing how the material is rendered new.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity
Description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of grades 6–8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 8 topics, texts, and issues, building on others’ ideas and expressing their own clearly.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Come to discussions prepared, having read or researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence on the topic, text, or issue to probe and reflect on ideas under discussion.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Follow rules for collegial discussions and decision-making, track progress toward specific goals and deadlines, and define individual roles as needed.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Pose questions that connect the ideas of several speakers and respond to others’ questions and comments with relevant evidence, observations, and ideas.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Acknowledge new information expressed by others, and, when warranted, qualify or justify their own views in light of the evidence presented.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze the purpose of information presented in diverse media and formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) and evaluate the motives (e.g., social, commercial, political) behind its presentation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Delineate a speaker’s argument and specific claims, evaluating the soundness of the reasoning and relevance and sufficiency of the evidence and identifying when irrelevant evidence is introduced.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Present claims and findings, emphasizing salient points in a focused, coherent manner with relevant evidence, sound valid reasoning, and well-chosen details; use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Integrate multimedia and visual displays into presentations to clarify information, strengthen claims and evidence, and add interest.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate. (See grade 8 Language standards 1 and 3 on page 53 for specific expectations.)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Introduce claim(s), acknowledge and distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and organize the reasons and evidence logically.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Support claim(s) with logical reasoning and relevant evidence, using accurate, credible sources and demonstrating an understanding of the topic or text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use words, phrases, and clauses to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Introduce a topic clearly, previewing what is to follow; organize ideas, concepts, and information into broader categories; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., charts, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Develop the topic with relevant, well-chosen facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use appropriate and varied transitions to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among ideas and concepts.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Engage and orient the reader by establishing a context and point of view and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally and logically.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, and reflection, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use a variety of transition words, phrases, and clauses to convey sequence, signal shifts from one time frame or setting to another, and show the relationships among experiences and events.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use precise words and phrases, relevant descriptive details, and sensory language to capture the action and convey experiences and events.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on the narrated experiences or events.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience. (Grade-specific expectations for writing types are defined in standards 1–3 above.)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With some guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on how well purpose and audience have been addressed. (Editing for conventions should demonstrate command of Language standards 1–3 up to and including grade 8 on page 53.)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and present the relationships between information and ideas efficiently as well as to interact and collaborate with others.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Conduct short research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question), drawing on several sources and generating additional related, focused questions that allow for multiple avenues of exploration.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, using search terms effectively; assess the credibility and accuracy of each source; and quote or paraphrase the data and conclusions of others while avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Apply grade 8 Reading standards to literature (e.g., “Analyze how a modern work of fiction draws on themes, patterns of events, or character types from myths, traditional stories, or religious works such as the Bible, including describing how the material is rendered new”).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Apply grade 8 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g., “Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced”).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Explain the function of phrases and clauses in general and their function in specific sentences.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Choose among simple, compound, complex, and compound-complex sentences to signal differing relationships among ideas.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Place phrases and clauses within a sentence, recognizing and correcting misplaced and dangling modifiers.*

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use a comma to separate coordinate adjectives (e.g., It was a fascinating, enjoyable movie but not He wore an old[,] green shirt).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Spell correctly.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Choose language that expresses ideas precisely and concisely, recognizing and eliminating wordiness and redundancy.*

Description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a word’s position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., belligerent, bellicose, rebel).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning or its part of speech.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Interpret figures of speech (e.g., literary, biblical, and mythological allusions) in context.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use the relationship between particular words (e.g., synonym/antonym, analogy) to better understand each of the words.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Distinguish among the connotations (associations) of words with similar denotations (definitions) (e.g., refined, respectful, polite, diplomatic, condescending).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Compare and contrast a text to an audio, video, or multimedia version of the text, analyzing each medium’s portrayal of the subject (e.g., how the delivery of a speech affects the impact of the words).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how two or more authors writing about the same topic shape their presentations of key information by emphasizing different evidence or advancing different interpretations of facts.

Description: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.

Description: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).

Description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) on a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how a drama’s or poem’s form or structure (e.g., soliloquy, sonnet) contributes to its meaning.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Compare and contrast a story, drama, or poem to its audio, filmed, staged, or multimedia version, analyzing the effects of techniques unique to each medium (e.g., lighting, sound, color, or camera focus and angles in a film).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Compare and contrast a fictional portrayal of a time, place, or character and a historical account of the same period as a means of understanding how authors of fiction use or alter history.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Conduct short research projects to answer a question, drawing on several sources and generating additional related, focused questions for further research and investigation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, using search terms effectively; assess the credibility and accuracy of each source; and quote or paraphrase the data and conclusions of others while avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Apply grade 7 Reading standards to literature (e.g., “Compare and contrast a fictional portrayal of a time, place, or character and a historical account of the same period as a means of understanding how authors of fiction use or alter history”).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Description: Apply grade 7 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g. “Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims”).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use parallel structure.*

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use various types of phrases (noun, verb, adjectival, adverbial, participial, prepositional, absolute) and clauses (independent, dependent; noun, relative, adverbial) to convey specific meanings and add variety and interest to writing or presentations.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use a semicolon (and perhaps a conjunctive adverb) to link two or more closely related independent clauses.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use a colon to introduce a list or quotation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Spell correctly.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write and edit work so that it conforms to the guidelines in a style manual (e.g., MLA Handbook, Turabian’s Manual for Writers) appropriate for the discipline and writing type.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 9–10 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence, paragraph, or text; a word’s position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Identify and correctly use patterns of word changes that indicate different meanings or parts of speech (e.g., analyze, analysis, analytical; advocate, advocacy).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning, its part of speech, or its etymology.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Interpret figures of speech (e.g., satire, sarcasm) in context and analyze their role in the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Acquire and use accurately general academic and domain-specific words and phrases, sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how the author unfolds an analysis or series of ideas or events, including the order in which the points are made, how they are introduced and developed, and the connections that are drawn between them.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the cumulative impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone (e.g., how the language of a court opinion differs from that of a newspaper).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze in detail how an author’s ideas or claims are developed and refined by particular sentences, paragraphs, or larger portions of a text (e.g., a section or chapter).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how an author uses rhetoric to advance that point of view or purpose.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze various accounts of a subject told in different mediums (e.g., a person’s life story in both print and multimedia), determining which details are emphasized in each account.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; identify false statements and fallacious reasoning.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze seminal U.S. documents of historical and literary significance (e.g., Washington’s Farewell Address, the Gettysburg Address, Roosevelt’s Four Freedoms speech, King’s "Letter From Birmingham Jail"), including how they address related themes and concepts.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: By the end of grade 9, read and comprehend literary nonfiction in the grades 9–10 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range. By the end of grade 10, read and comprehend literary nonfiction at the high end of the grades 9–10 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how complex characters (e.g., those with multiple or conflicting motivations) develop over the course of a text, interact with other characters, and advance the plot or develop the theme.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the cumulative impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone (e.g., how the language evokes a sense of time and place; how it sets a formal or informal tone).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how an author’s choices concerning how to structure a text, order events within it (e.g., parallel plots), and manipulate time (e.g., pacing, flashbacks) create such effects as mystery, tension, or surprise.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze a particular point of view or cultural experience reflected in a work of literature from outside the United States, drawing on a wide reading of world literature.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze the representation of a subject or a key scene in two different artistic mediums, including what is emphasized or absent in each treatment (e.g., Auden’s “Musée des Beaux Arts” and Breughel’s Landscape with the Fall of Icarus).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how an author draws on and transforms source material in a specific work (e.g., how Shakespeare treats a theme or topic from Ovid or the Bible or how a later author draws on a play by Shakespeare).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: By the end of grade 9, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 9–10 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range. By the end of grade 10, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of the grades 9–10 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grades 9–10 topics, texts, and issues, building on others’ ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Come to discussions prepared, having read and researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence from texts and other research on the topic or issue to stimulate a thoughtful, well-reasoned exchange of ideas.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Work with peers to set rules for collegial discussions and decision-making (e.g., informal consensus, taking votes on key issues, presentation of alternate views), clear goals and deadlines, and individual roles as needed.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Propel conversations by posing and responding to questions that relate the current discussion to broader themes or larger ideas; actively incorporate others into the discussion; and clarify, verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Respond thoughtfully to diverse perspectives, summarize points of agreement and disagreement, and, when warranted, qualify or justify their own views and understanding and make new connections in light of the evidence and reasoning presented.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Integrate multiple sources of information presented in diverse media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) evaluating the credibility and accuracy of each source.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Evaluate a speaker’s point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric, identifying any fallacious reasoning or exaggerated or distorted evidence.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Present information, findings, and supporting evidence clearly, concisely, and logically such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning and the organization, development, substance, and style are appropriate to purpose, audience, and task.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Make strategic use of digital media (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and interactive elements) in presentations to enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence and to add interest.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate. (See grades 9-10 Language standards 1 and 3 on pages 54 for specific expectations.)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Introduce precise claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization that establishes clear relationships among claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly, supplying evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience’s knowledge level and concerns.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use words, phrases, and clauses to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Introduce a topic; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information to make important connections and distinctions; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Develop the topic with well-chosen, relevant, and sufficient facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience’s knowledge of the topic.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use appropriate and varied transitions to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to manage the complexity of the topic.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and introducing a narrator and/or characters; create a smooth progression of experiences or events.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple plot lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the narrative.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience. (Grade-specific expectations for writing types are defined in standards 1–3 above.)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience. (Editing for conventions should demonstrate command of Language standards 1–3 on up to and including grades 9-10 page 55.)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products, taking advantage of technology’s capacity to link to other information and to display information flexibly and dynamically.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the usefulness of each source in answering the research question; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Apply grades 9–10 Reading standards to literature(e.g., “Analyze how an author draws on and transforms source material in a specific work [e.g., how Shakespeare treats a theme or topic from Ovid or the Bible or how a later author draws on a play by Shakespeare]”).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Apply grades 9–10 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g., “Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; identify false statements and fallacious reasoning”).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of primary and secondary sources, attending to such features as the date and origin of the information.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine the central ideas or information of a primary or secondary source; provide an accurate summary of how key events or ideas develop over the course of the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze in detail a series of events described in a text; determine whether earlier events caused later ones or simply preceded them.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including vocabulary describing political, social, or economic aspects of history/social science.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how a text uses structure to emphasize key points or advance an explanation or analysis.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Compare the point of view of two or more authors for how they treat the same or similar topics, including which details they include and emphasize in their respective accounts.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Integrate quantitative or technical analysis (e.g., charts, research data) with qualitative analysis in print or digital text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Assess the extent to which the reasoning and evidence in a text support the author's claims.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Compare and contrast treatments of the same topic in several primary and secondary sources.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: By the end of grade 10, read and comprehend history, social studies texts in the grades 9-10 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of science and technical texts, attending to the precise details of explanations or descriptions.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: Determine the central ideas or conclusions of a text; trace the text's explanation or depiction of a complex process, phenomenon, or concept; provide an accurate summary of the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: Follow precisely a complex multistep procedure when carrying out experiments, taking measurements, or performing technical tasks attending to special cases or exceptions defined in the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: Determine the meaning of symbols, key terms, and other domain-specific words and phrases as they are used in a specific scientific or technical context relevant to grades 9-10 texts and topics.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: Analyze the structure of the relationships among concepts in a text, including relationships among key terms (e.g., force, friction, reaction force, energy).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: Analyze the author's purpose in providing an explanation, describing a procedure, or discussing an experiment in a text, defining the question the author seeks to address.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: Translate quantitative or technical information expressed in words in a text into visual form (e.g., a table or chart) and translate information expressed visually or mathematically (e.g., in an equation) into words.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: Assess the extent to which the reasoning and evidence in a text support the auhor's claim or a recommendation for solving a scientific or technical problem.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: Compare and contrast findings presented in a text to those from other sources (including their own experiments), noting when the findings support or contradict previous explanations or accounts.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: By the end of grade 10, read and comprehend science/technical texts in the grades 9-10 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

Category: Writing Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Ensure that pronouns are in the proper case (subjective, objective, possessive).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use intensive pronouns (e.g., myself, ourselves).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in pronoun number and person.*

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Recognize and correct vague pronouns (i.e., ones with unclear or ambiguous antecedents).*

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Recognize variations from standard English in their own and others' writing and speaking, and identify and use strategies to improve expression in conventional language.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use punctuation (commas, parentheses, dashes) to set off nonrestrictive/parenthetical elements.*

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Spell correctly.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Choose language that expresses ideas precisely and concisely, recognizing and eliminating wordiness and redundancy.*

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Maintain consistency in style and tone.*

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

Description: Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a word’s position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., audience, auditory, audible).

Description: Consult reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning or its part of speech.

Description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Interpret figures of speech (e.g., personification) in context.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use the relationship between particular words (e.g., cause/effect, part/whole, item/category) to better understand each of the words.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Distinguish among the connotations (associations) of words with similar denotations (definitions) (e.g., stingy, scrimping, economical, unwasteful, thrifty).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.

Description: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Integrate information presented in different media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively) as well as in words to develop a coherent understanding of a topic or issue.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Compare and contrast one author’s presentation of events with that of another (e.g., a memoir written by and a biography on the same person).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity
Description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literary nonfiction in the grades 6–8 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Describe how a particular story’s or drama’s plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Explain how an author develops the point of view of the narrator or speaker in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Compare and contrast the experience of reading a story, drama, or poem to listening to or viewing an audio, video, or live version of the text, including contrasting what they “see” and “hear” when reading the text to what they perceive when they listen or watch.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Compare and contrast texts in different forms or genres (e.g., stories and poems; historical novels and fantasy stories) in terms of their approaches to similar themes and topics.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity
Description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 6–8 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 6 topics, texts, and issues, building on others’ ideas and expressing their own clearly.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Come to discussions prepared, having read or studied required material; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence on the topic, text, or issue to probe and reflect on ideas under discussion.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Follow rules for collegial discussions, set specific goals and deadlines, and define individual roles as needed.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Pose and respond to specific questions with elaboration and detail by making comments that contribute to the topic, text, or issue under discussion.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Review the key ideas expressed and demonstrate understanding of multiple perspectives through reflection and paraphrasing.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Interpret information presented in diverse media and formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) and explain how it contributes to a topic, text, or issue under study.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Delineate a speaker’s argument and specific claims, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Present claims and findings, sequencing ideas logically and using pertinent descriptions, facts, and details to accentuate main ideas or themes; use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Include multimedia components (e.g., graphics, images, music, sound) and visual displays in presentations to clarify information.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate. (See grade 6 Language standards 1 and 3 on page 53 for specific expectations.)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Introduce claim(s) and organize the reasons and evidence clearly.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Support claim(s) with clear reasons and relevant evidence, using credible sources and demonstrating an understanding of the topic or text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use words, phrases, and clauses to clarify the relationships among claim(s) and reasons.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from the argument presented.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Introduce a topic; organize ideas, concepts, and information, using strategies such as definition, classification, comparison/contrast, and cause/effect; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., charts, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Develop the topic with relevant facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use appropriate transitions to clarify the relationships among ideas and concepts.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from the information or explanation presented.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Engage and orient the reader by establishing a context and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally and logically.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, and description, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use a variety of transition words, phrases, and clauses to convey sequence and signal shifts from one time frame or setting to another.

Subject: Lang/Arts

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Provide a conclusion that follows from the narrated experiences or events.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience. (Grade-specific expectations for writing types are defined in standards 1–3 above.)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: With some guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach.(Editing for conventions should demonstrate command of Language standards 1–3up to and including grade 6 on page53.)

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing as well as to interact and collaborate with others; demonstrate sufficient command of keyboarding skills to type a minimum of three pages in a single sitting.

Description: Conduct short research projects to answer a question, drawing on several sources and refocusing the inquiry when appropriate.

Subject: Lang/Arts

Subject: Lang/Arts

Subject: Lang/Arts
Subcategory: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

Subject: Lang/Arts

Subject: Lang/Arts

Subject: Lang/Arts

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including vocabulary specific to domains related to history/social studies.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Describe how a text presents information (e.g., sequentially, comparatively, causally).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Identify aspects of a text that reveal an author's point of view or purpose (e.g., loaded language, inclusion or avoidance of particular facts).

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Integrate visual information (e.g., in charts, graphs, photographs, videos, or maps) with other information in pprint and digital texts.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Distinguish among fact, opinion, and reasoned judgment in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Analyze the relationship between a primary and secondary source on the same topic.

Category: Reading Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects
Description: Distinguish among facts, reasoned judgment based on research findings, and speculation in a text.

Subject: Lang/Arts

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Writing Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects

Category: Writing Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects
Description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.

Category: Writing Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects
Description: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Category: Writing Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects
Description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented.

Category: Writing Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects
Description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

Category: Writing Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects
Description: With some guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on how well purpose and audience have been addressed.

Subject: Lang/Arts

Subject: Lang/Arts

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Explain the function of conjunctions, prepositions, and interjections in general and their function in particular sentences.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Form and use the perfect (e.g., I had walked; I have walked; I will have walked) verb tenses.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use verb tense to convey various times, sequences, states, and conditions.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense.*

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use correlative conjunctions (e.g., either/or, neither/nor).

Description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

Subject: Lang/Arts

Description: Use a comma to separate an introductory element from the rest of the sentence.

Subject: Lang/Arts
Description: Use underlining, quotation marks, or italics to indicate titles of works.

Description: Spell grade-appropriate words correctly, consulting references as needed.

Subject: Lang/Arts

Description: Compare and contrast the varieties of English (e.g., dialects, registers) used in stories, dramas, or poems.

Subject: Lang/Arts
